text: I tend to write about the Stars Reach pre-alpha tests that come up on the weekends as that is when new features show up and we’re allowed to see a new evolution of the game and its potential mechanics. Stars Reach There are, on occasion, additional test that happen during the week.  I have mentioned them in passing before, usually to say that I couldn’t make it to this one or that one due to life getting in the way.  They’ll try to get one in during the morning hours Pacific time usually, so that our European cousins can get in and test as well.  I think that is when Bhagpuss gets to join in. So the downside is that weekdays are not always clear on my calendar.  But the upside, when I can get on, is that the data from the weekend tests are often carried over, so your old character’s, and their progression, are saved and can be resumed.  These are very important things in any aspiring MMORPG.  Also, my complaint previously, that two hours of play time was not enough, can be alleviated a bit if can return to a character already in motion. Fortunately, this past week, I did manage to find some time for the weeknight tests.  On Wednesday night I was only able to get in for the tail end of the two hours, but it was enough to get me started.  My goal: to craft the grav mesh, the levitation item that I enjoyed in early tests when the team was giving us stuff up front. So once I heard the servers were open on Discord, I was in and ready to go. Into the world again I landed on the desert planet… it is a random pick which planet you start on when you log in… but my destination was space.  I went through the portal.  I also disconnected from the Discord voice channel.  There is a balance that is sometimes out of whack there, between devs giving us information and people being helpful and people resolutely rambling on out their video game history and other topics which, from strangers, is not always as interesting as they think. Also, I wanted a bit of quiet to focus.  I don’t play other video games with that many people yakking away. Once in space I had to fill out my need for metals, digging carefully into asteroids looking for chromium or like options in the right tier. The resource list for crafting I needed tier 3 metals and industrial gems for the grav mesh.  The metals were easy enough to find.  I managed to mine in space and only died twice to the game deciding my position was untenable and just killing me out of hand. Space mining safety The gems, however, remained elusive.  I had, however, previously found some on the jungle planet.  So I found the portal that would take to the jungle planet and starting digging around.  It looked like all the gems that had been visible from the surface had been dug out… again, the world was preserved from the weekend test and stuff doesn’t magically respawn… so I spent some time digging into various rock formations until I ran across some quartz.  I checked the list of resources, and that looked like it would fit the bill. I wasn’t sure how much I would need, so I just piled on a bunch, making a little protective wall around the excavation with my tailings… we’ve been told that will be fixed at some point, that tailings won’t be a magic building block at some future point… and once I felts like I had enough, went back to the spawn… the /camp command is currently handy for that… and found the crafting station. Grav Mesh crafted! Once crafted, I dug around a bit until I figured out how to equip it… aside from swapping tools occasionally I haven’t done much with gear… and put it on.  Flying was now enabled. Moving through the air Flying within limits at least.  The grav mesh draws from your stamina, so it isn’t the completely OP introduction of something like flying mounts that have marred the experience of some games.  But it is handy and fun and required at times to reach some parts of the world. With that equipped my next goal was to finish up the survey for the jungle planet.  Once again, my progress had been saved so I only had five more to find.  The first three were easy.  One was up high, so the grav mesh helped a lot.  But when I got down to the final pair the survey map led me back to the lava. Back to the lava field There were two more survey points down there, and they were tough to see on that orange background.  But flying over and moving around I was able to spot both.  I was the only one on that mission that night however, so I had to get down there and freeze my way to them in order to register them. Freezing lava so I can move across it There are some, more deft that me, who can use the grav mesh to fly out, hover, and register the locations, but I am not that adept.  I did it old school, though there is a directional aspect to it, because when you have the ranger tool in hand, which has the freeze ray, you cannot see the survey node.  So you have to swap over to the survey tool to see that… and then you’re not freezing things and that can catch up with you fact if you’re not careful. The grav mesh did mean I was able to exit easily.  Without that you have to freeze your way back to land as things only stay frozen somewhat briefly in the lava.  As I said, that can catch up with you fast. That got me the final two survey points and the trophy for the achievement. Survey complete At that point we were less than an hour into that evening’s test.  I can move when I focus. Having done one planet, I went back to the portal and returned to space to find the portal to one of the two remaining planets. Space as a transit point I guess… the beacon marks a portal Through the portal I found myself back on the desert world again.  I pulled up the survey map and found that I had zero survey points marked.  I realized that I had done any surveying with other characters that past weekend, characters that were both now broken.  So it was time to start from scratch, with 64 nodes to register.  Off I went. Heading into the desert Well, with the grav mesh and an hour to play, I was game.  Off I went, collecting all the survey nodes.  Some were high, some were low, some were right on the edge of the map. In the cactus by the blue wall that marks the edge of the world Once again, the grav mesh enabled my quick progress, allowing me to get up to high places, skirt danger, and get a vantage point in the sky to find the next node. Through the night sky of the desert planet I managed to get to 63 of 64 nodes.  However, I was thwarted at the final node.  I mentioned in the last post the pyramid where all the ballhog mobs seemed to congregate on the desert planet. The ballhog mobs seem to live here Well, the last survey node to register was in the pyramid.  I could see it blinking to me as I approached the area. The blink is coming from withing the structure… note my red corpse marker However, it wasn’t simply inside the building.  I made runs at that over and over and it was not visible.  Nor could you register it from outside the building.  I tried that over and over and was never successful.  I suspected it might be under the building and got out the digging tool and undermined the corner of the pyramid, but had not luck there.  And, with each attempt I was swarmed but the mobs and died.  That got tedious after a while and eventually I just gave up on the venture and spent some time dancing at the main camp to help people recover diminished health and stamina. Despite being thwarted in my goal, it was a good evening of trying out the game, marked as it was by no crashes on my part.  That is a first for a play test for me.  Then again, it did seem like a smaller crowd testing, so perhaps that helped. Meanwhile, it seems like housing and homesteading might be coming up in testing soon. As always, these are pre-alpha tests and any similarity between this and what actually shipped will likely be purely coincidental.  We shall see. html:
I tend to write about the Stars Reach pre-alpha tests that come up on the weekends as that is when new features show up and we’re allowed to see a new evolution of the game and its potential mechanics.

Stars Reach

There are, on occasion, additional test that happen during the week.  I have mentioned them in passing before, usually to say that I couldn’t make it to this one or that one due to life getting in the way.  They’ll try to get one in during the morning hours Pacific time usually, so that our European cousins can get in and test as well.  I think that is when Bhagpuss gets to join in.

So the downside is that weekdays are not always clear on my calendar.  But the upside, when I can get on, is that the data from the weekend tests are often carried over, so your old character’s, and their progression, are saved and can be resumed.  These are very important things in any aspiring MMORPG.  Also, my complaint previously, that two hours of play time was not enough, can be alleviated a bit if can return to a character already in motion.

Fortunately, this past week, I did manage to find some time for the weeknight tests.  On Wednesday night I was only able to get in for the tail end of the two hours, but it was enough to get me started.  My goal: to craft the grav mesh, the levitation item that I enjoyed in early tests when the team was giving us stuff up front.

So once I heard the servers were open on Discord, I was in and ready to go.

Into the world again

I landed on the desert planet… it is a random pick which planet you start on when you log in… but my destination was space.  I went through the portal.  I also disconnected from the Discord voice channel.  There is a balance that is sometimes out of whack there, between devs giving us information and people being helpful and people resolutely rambling on out their video game history and other topics which, from strangers, is not always as interesting as they think.

Also, I wanted a bit of quiet to focus.  I don’t play other video games with that many people yakking away.

Once in space I had to fill out my need for metals, digging carefully into asteroids looking for chromium or like options in the right tier.

The resource list for crafting

I needed tier 3 metals and industrial gems for the grav mesh.  The metals were easy enough to find.  I managed to mine in space and only died twice to the game deciding my position was untenable and just killing me out of hand.

Space mining safety

The gems, however, remained elusive.  I had, however, previously found some on the jungle planet.  So I found the portal that would take to the jungle planet and starting digging around.  It looked like all the gems that had been visible from the surface had been dug out… again, the world was preserved from the weekend test and stuff doesn’t magically respawn… so I spent some time digging into various rock formations until I ran across some quartz.  I checked the list of resources, and that looked like it would fit the bill.

I wasn’t sure how much I would need, so I just piled on a bunch, making a little protective wall around the excavation with my tailings… we’ve been told that will be fixed at some point, that tailings won’t be a magic building block at some future point… and once I felts like I had enough, went back to the spawn… the /camp command is currently handy for that… and found the crafting station.

Grav Mesh crafted!

Once crafted, I dug around a bit until I figured out how to equip it… aside from swapping tools occasionally I haven’t done much with gear… and put it on.  Flying was now enabled.

Moving through the air

Flying within limits at least.  The grav mesh draws from your stamina, so it isn’t the completely OP introduction of something like flying mounts that have marred the experience of some games.  But it is handy and fun and required at times to reach some parts of the world.

With that equipped my next goal was to finish up the survey for the jungle planet.  Once again, my progress had been saved so I only had five more to find.  The first three were easy.  One was up high, so the grav mesh helped a lot.  But when I got down to the final pair the survey map led me back to the lava.

Back to the lava field

There were two more survey points down there, and they were tough to see on that orange background.  But flying over and moving around I was able to spot both.  I was the only one on that mission that night however, so I had to get down there and freeze my way to them in order to register them.

Freezing lava so I can move across it

There are some, more deft that me, who can use the grav mesh to fly out, hover, and register the locations, but I am not that adept.  I did it old school, though there is a directional aspect to it, because when you have the ranger tool in hand, which has the freeze ray, you cannot see the survey node.  So you have to swap over to the survey tool to see that… and then you’re not freezing things and that can catch up with you fact if you’re not careful.

The grav mesh did mean I was able to exit easily.  Without that you have to freeze your way back to land as things only stay frozen somewhat briefly in the lava.  As I said, that can catch up with you fast.

That got me the final two survey points and the trophy for the achievement.

Survey complete

At that point we were less than an hour into that evening’s test.  I can move when I focus.

Having done one planet, I went back to the portal and returned to space to find the portal to one of the two remaining planets.

Space as a transit point I guess… the beacon marks a portal

Through the portal I found myself back on the desert world again.  I pulled up the survey map and found that I had zero survey points marked.  I realized that I had done any surveying with other characters that past weekend, characters that were both now broken.  So it was time to start from scratch, with 64 nodes to register.  Off I went.

Heading into the desert

Well, with the grav mesh and an hour to play, I was game.  Off I went, collecting all the survey nodes.  Some were high, some were low, some were right on the edge of the map.

In the cactus by the blue wall that marks the edge of the world

Once again, the grav mesh enabled my quick progress, allowing me to get up to high places, skirt danger, and get a vantage point in the sky to find the next node.

Through the night sky of the desert planet

I managed to get to 63 of 64 nodes.  However, I was thwarted at the final node.  I mentioned in the last post the pyramid where all the ballhog mobs seemed to congregate on the desert planet.

The ballhog mobs seem to live here

Well, the last survey node to register was in the pyramid.  I could see it blinking to me as I approached the area.

The blink is coming from withing the structure… note my red corpse marker

However, it wasn’t simply inside the building.  I made runs at that over and over and it was not visible.  Nor could you register it from outside the building.  I tried that over and over and was never successful.  I suspected it might be under the building and got out the digging tool and undermined the corner of the pyramid, but had not luck there.  And, with each attempt I was swarmed but the mobs and died.  That got tedious after a while and eventually I just gave up on the venture and spent some time dancing at the main camp to help people recover diminished health and stamina.

Despite being thwarted in my goal, it was a good evening of trying out the game, marked as it was by no crashes on my part.  That is a first for a play test for me.  Then again, it did seem like a smaller crowd testing, so perhaps that helped.

Meanwhile, it seems like housing and homesteading might be coming up in testing soon.

As always, these are pre-alpha tests and any similarity between this and what actually shipped will likely be purely coincidental.  We shall see.
